Description: Painted glass inlay plaque; rectangular concave plaque, the two side edges curving upward; top and bottom edges are straight, side edges bevelled; painting in black lines on concave front side; rectangular frame containing winged male sphinx in Egyptian style advancing to left toward lotus bud on high stem. The sphinx wears a wig, above it uraeus and solar disc, a simplified pectoral and 'apron'. In front of his chest is another uraeus wearing something similar to the crown of Lower Egypt and above it is a solar disc. No visible traces of beard; traces of blue paint on 'apron' and on lower uraeus and possible trace of red paint on the upper solar disc; cast, perhaps in flat one-piece mould and shaped by reheating and rolling on convex surface; painted with ordinary paints (i.e. not enamelled); glass deteriorated and turned into an opaque whitish material; iridescent; small chip off lower left corner.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: British School of Archaeology, Iraq
Curator's comments: Tait 1991 Probably made as one of a set to decorate furniture during the reign of the Assyrian king Tiglath-Pileser III (744-727 BC).
Bibliographic references: Tait 1991 / Five Thousand Years of Glass (fig.41, p.39)
Barag 1985a / Catalogue of Western Asiatic glass in the British Museum, Volume I (52)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2007-2008 6 Oct-20 Apr, Paris, L'Institut du Monde Arabe, 'Phoenicians and the Mediterranean'. 1958 BM, G58/Nimrud Ivories
Condition: Fair; incomplete; glass deteriorated and turned into an opaque whitish material; iridescent; small chip off lower left corner.
Acquisition notes: Acquisition noted in the 'British Museum Quarterly' 32 (1967/68), p.58.
